Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Nanostructured wear and corrosion resistant surfaces for titanium and titanium alloy applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project affects all industries that employ mechanical components fabricated from titanium or titanium alloys. The ability to solve the problems of poor wear resistance of titanium and titanium alloys facilitates and accelerates the utilization of titanium alloys for mechanical components in many markets. This is especially beneficial for those markets that require materials with high corrosion resistance, the capacity to handle high temperatures, and materials that possess a high tensile strength to density ratio. This technology will potential significantly benefit first markets in the automotive and aerospace industries where titanium utilization is expected to grow significantly. The potential of this project can also extend to biomedical devices and components such as medical implants. Additive manufacturing technologies have accelerated the growth of titanium-containing materials in these and other markets, and this project should contribute synergistically with advanced manufacturing initiatives.

This I-Corps project will further develop a new surface treatment for titanium and titanium alloys. The surface treatment consists of a modified oxide layer produced through thermochemical processes. After initially generating an oxide layer, a post nitriding process produces a unique structure containing nanocrystalline titanium nitride in a titanium dioxide matrix. The wear and corrosion resistance of specimens with this surface treatment have been benchmarked against untreated specimens and specimens treated with other commercially available engineered surfaces. The nanocomposite converted surfaces were shown to provide a 300x improvement in the wear resistance in dry and tribocorrosive environments, and a 10x improvement over thermal oxidation and nitriding. This technology is an improvement over previous attempts used to attain this unique surface morphology that used toxic chemicals that leave hazardous contaminants in the coating.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2019, Precision Surface Science was awarded an opportunity to participate in an I-CORPS Teams cohort (Award #1941247) by the National Science Foundation. 

During the rigorous seven week I-Corps program, we interviewed 110 engineers working in the transportation, medical, and recreational sports industries to study the commercialization potential of our titanium surface engineering technology. Initially, our team thought that the automotive industry, particularly motorsports, would be interested in a solution that would allow them to run a lighter piston at higher temperatures. However, we found that most manufacturers do not use titanium alloys due its poor wear resistance and high cost. Although our technology does mitigate the wear issue, the larger concern was the cost, which we could not address.

We learned that although engineers in the automotive industry are concerned with reducing weight and emissions, they prefer to use aluminum and magnesium alloys due to the lower cost, lighter weight, and less difficulty in forming. We also learned that these materials also suffer from the same wear problems that titanium does. After interviewing approximately 75 engineers in the automotive industry, we determined that our technology was not well aligned with their primary needs, so we pivoted to probe the medical industry.

Speaking to orthopedic surgeons, technology scouts, and medical device engineers, we learned that the medical industry?s primary needs are anti-microbial coatings to prevent infections and surfaces on implantable devices that can improve osseointegration (the ability of an implant to form strong bonds to bones). We also learned that although wear can sometimes be an issue and that many surgeons prefer titanium over cobalt-chrome due to safety concerns, implants typically last the anticipated time in most cases and infections are what plague the industry. After speaking to technology scouts to understand the process of adopting new technologies, we learned that, although they were interested in and valued our titanium surface treatment technology, the burden of proof to demonstrate anti-microbial and osseointegration improvement would be on us before the technology would be clinically evaluated.

Our findings suggest that this technology has potential applications in medical technologies, however, finding ways to translate the technology to aluminum and magnesium alloys to address the needs of the transportation industry was determined to be the more efficient commercialization pathway and the more likely means of making a positive impact of society.

Our technology has the potential to broadly impact society in many ways, but we expect the greatest impact to be primarily in aerospace and automotive technologies. Specifically, this technology can enable lightweight metals to be used in many components where they can not currently be used.  By reducing the mass of engine and chassis components, the fuel efficiency of a vehicle or aircraft can be improved. Improving the efficiency of internal combustion vehicles, our technology could lead to reduced emissions and help slow climate change.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2020
Modified by: Gary L Doll
